text: I always tell them to optimize for the problems they want to have. You want the problem of customers getting through your funnel, feeling successful, using your product and getting value and then saying to you, "Oh, but I need it on this platform, or I need this capability, or I want to be able to share this." I mean you want those problems. So don't do those features now.
speaker: Scott Belsky
context: Lenny asks Scott about his advice to only build half the features you want to build and how to decide which features to include in an MVP. Scott explains his philosophy of prioritizing the core user journey over additional features. He believes teams should focus on eliminating fundamental barriers that prevent users from experiencing value, rather than building nice-to-have features that users will only request once they're already engaged.
vocabulary_highlights: optimize for the problems you want to have
text_ko: 저는 항상 이렇게 말해요. 당신이 '겪고 싶어 하는' 문제들에 맞춰 최적화하라고요. 예를 들어 고객들이 퍼널(funnel)을 잘 통과해서 성공감을 느끼고, 제품을 써서 가치를 얻은 다음에 "아, 그런데 이 플랫폼(platform)에도 필요해요", "이런 기능(capability)이 필요해요", "이걸 공유하고 싶어요"라고 말하게 되는 그런 문제들을 원한다는 거예요. 그런 문제들이 생기길 바라니까 지금 당장 그런 기능(features)을 만들지 마세요.
text_zh: 我总是跟他们说，要为你想要的问题做优化。你希望遇到的问题应该是客户顺利通过你的漏斗(funnel)，感到成功，使用你的产品并获得价值，然后对你说："哎，但是我需要在这个平台上用，或者我需要这个功能，或者我想能够分享这个。" 我的意思是你就想要这些问题。所以现在别急着做那些功能。
text_es: Siempre les digo que se enfoquen en los problemas que sí quieren tener. Quieren el problema de que los clientes pasen por su embudo (funnel), se sientan exitosos, usen su producto y obtengan valor, y después les digan: "Oye, pero lo necesito en esta plataforma, o necesito esta funcionalidad, o quiero poder compartir esto." O sea, esos son los problemas que quieren tener. Así que no desarrollen esas características ahorita.
key_sentence: Optimize for the problems you want to have, not features you don't need.

text: In the first 30 seconds of using a new product, you are lazy, vain, and selfish. You want to get it done super quickly. You want to look good to your colleagues or to your friends. You want to feel successful very quickly by engaging in this product. You don't want to have to watch a tour or read anything, really endure any learning curve whatsoever.
speaker: Scott Belsky
context: Lenny asks Scott how he built his product sense and what advice he has for younger PMs. Scott explains his framework about the psychology of first-time users, describing what he calls the 'first mile' experience. He argues that understanding human psychology is crucial for product development, particularly recognizing that new users have very specific mental states and low tolerance for friction when they first encounter a product.
text_ko: 새 제품을 처음 써보는 첫 30초 동안은 사람들은 게으르고, 허영심 많고, 이기적이에요. 일은 정말 빨리 끝내고 싶어하고, 동료나 친구들에게 잘 보이고 싶어해요. 이 제품을 쓰면서 금방 성공한 느낌을 받고 싶어해요. 제품 투어를 보거나 뭔가를 읽고 싶지 않고, 어떤 학습 곡선(learning curve)도 겪고 싶어하지 않아요.
text_zh: 用户在使用新产品的前30秒，基本上都是懒、爱面子、还很自私的。他们就想快速搞定，想在同事或朋友面前显得很厉害，想马上就有成就感。他们可不想看什么产品介绍，也不想读说明，更不想经历任何学习过程。
text_es: En los primeros 30 segundos usando un producto nuevo, eres flojo, vanidoso y egoísta. Quieres que todo salga súper rápido. Quieres quedar bien con tus colegas o amigos. Quieres sentirte exitoso de inmediato al usar este producto. No quieres tener que ver un tutorial ni leer nada, en realidad no quieres lidiar con ninguna curva de aprendizaje (learning curve).
key_sentence: You are lazy, vain, and selfish when using a new product; avoid learning curves.

text: If you've lost conviction, you should not be doing what you're doing in the world of entrepreneurship. And I'll tell you, I get different answers. Some people are like, "Oh, Scott, I mean, I have more conviction. All that I've learned, all the validation I've received from customers, we just haven't figured it out yet. It's driving me crazy."
speaker: Scott Belsky
context: Lenny asks about Scott's advice on when founders should quit versus persevere through difficult times. Scott shares his framework for helping founders make this decision by asking them to evaluate their current conviction level compared to when they started. He explains that founders who maintain or increase conviction despite setbacks should continue, while those who have lost belief in their solution should consider pivoting or quitting entirely.
vocabulary_highlights: just haven't figured it out yet
text_ko: 확신을 잃었다면, 기업가 정신의 세계에서 지금 하고 있는 일을 계속하면 안 돼요. 제가 여러 사람에게 물어보면, 반응이 다 달라요. 어떤 사람들은 "아, 스콧, 나는 더 확신이 있어요. 내가 배운 것들, 고객들한테 받은 검증들, 아직 해결하지 못한 것들 뿐이에요. 이게 나를 미치게 해요."라고 하더라고요.
text_zh: 如果你对自己做的事情没信心了，那你就不应该搞创业这一套。我跟你说，我得到的回答各种各样。有些人会说："哦，Scott，我的信心其实更足了。我学到的这些东西，客户给我的这些验证，我们只是还没找到门道而已。这事儿快把我逼疯了。"
text_es: Si has perdido la convicción, no deberías estar haciendo lo que estás haciendo en el mundo del emprendimiento. Y te digo, recibo respuestas muy diferentes. Algunas personas me dicen: "Ay, Scott, o sea, tengo más convicción que nunca. Todo lo que he aprendido, toda la validación que he recibido de los clientes, simplemente no hemos dado en el clavo todavía. Me tiene loco."
key_sentence: Lost conviction means you shouldn't be in entrepreneurship; it's driving me crazy.

text: I love bringing design upstream. In fact, that's probably been the cheat code of my career as a product leader, has just been disproportionately empowering design throughout the process.
speaker: Scott Belsky
context: Lenny asks Scott about how he's helping PMs at Adobe leverage AI tools and new ways of working. Scott explains his approach to product development, emphasizing the importance of involving designers earlier in the product development process rather than just at the end for visual execution. He describes this as collapsing traditional organizational boundaries between product management and design functions.
text_ko: 저는 디자인을 초기 단계부터 참여시키는 걸 정말 좋아해요(bringing design upstream). 사실 제품 리더로서 제 커리어에서 그게 거의 치트 코드(cheat code)였어요 — 프로세스 전반에 걸쳐 디자인에 훨씬 더 많은 권한을 실어준 것이죠.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢把设计往前提，提到整个流程的上游去。说实话，这可能就是我作为产品负责人的一个秘诀吧，就是在整个过程中给设计更大的话语权，让它发挥更重要的作用。
text_es: Me encanta meter el diseño desde el principio del proceso. De hecho, esa ha sido probablemente la clave secreta de mi carrera como líder de producto: darle un peso desproporcionadamente grande al diseño en todo el proceso.
key_sentence: Bringing design upstream has been the cheat code of my career as a product leader.

text: If resources are carbs, resourcefulness is like muscle. It stays with you. It makes you stronger, and it helps you have a better intuition and better performance over time. I've always found that resourcefulness brings you further than resources despite the fact that over the last seven to 10 years, we've basically thrown resources at every problem.
speaker: Scott Belsky
context: Scott shares his final words of wisdom for product builders, focusing on the current economic environment where companies have fewer resources. He contrasts the recent trend of solving problems by throwing money and headcount at them versus being forced to find more creative, efficient solutions. Scott argues this resource-constrained environment actually creates opportunities for teams to develop stronger problem-solving capabilities.
vocabulary_highlights: resourcefulness brings you further than resources
text_ko: 자원(resources)이 탄수화물이라면, 자원 활용력(resourcefulness)은 근육 같아요. 몸에 남아서 점점 더 강하게 해주고, 시간이 지날수록 직관력과 성과도 더 좋아지게 해줘요. 지난 7~10년 동안 사실상 모든 문제에 자원을 쏟아부었지만, 저는 항상 자원 활용력(resourcefulness)이 자원(resources)보다 더 멀리 데려다준다는 걸 느껴왔어요.
text_zh: 如果说资源就像碳水化合物的话，那么机智应变(resourcefulness)就像肌肉一样。它会一直跟着你，让你变得更强，时间长了你的直觉会更准，表现也会更好。我一直觉得机智应变比光有资源更能让你走得远，虽然这七八年来，我们基本上遇到什么问题都是拿资源砸。
text_es: Si los recursos son como los carbohidratos, el ingenio es como el músculo. Se queda contigo. Te hace más fuerte y te ayuda a desarrollar mejor intuición y mejor rendimiento con el tiempo. Siempre he visto que el ingenio te lleva más lejos que los recursos, a pesar de que en los últimos siete a diez años básicamente hemos estado tirando recursos a cada problema que surge.
key_sentence: Resourcefulness brings you further than resources, making you stronger over time.

text: Creative professionals can now explore 10X the surface area of possibility. These tools are making them so much more efficient. And some people are like, "Oh my gosh, creative pros are going to be replaced." No. No, no, no. They're not. They're just going to find 10X better solutions.
speaker: Scott Belsky
context: Lenny asks Scott to talk about what Adobe is working on and Scott explains three waves of transformation driving Adobe's strategy. One key wave is how AI tools are empowering creative professionals rather than replacing them. Scott argues that generative AI allows designers and creatives to explore far more possibilities in the same amount of time, leading to better creative solutions rather than job displacement.
text_ko: 크리에이티브 전문가들은 이제 탐색할 수 있는 가능성의 폭을 10배(10X)로 넓혀볼 수 있어요. 이런 도구들 덕분에 훨씬 더 효율적으로 일하게 됐고요. 그러면 어떤 사람들은 "오 마이 갓, 창의 전문가들이 대체되는 거 아니야?"라고 말해요. 아니에요. 전혀 아니에요. 그들은 사라지는 게 아니라, 단지 10배 더 나은 해결책을 찾아내게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 现在创意工作者能探索的可能性比以前多了十倍。这些工具让他们的效率大大提升。有些人就说"哎呀，创意专业人士要被取代了"。不对，完全不是这么回事。他们不会被取代，只是能找到比现在好十倍的解决方案。
text_es: Los profesionales creativos ahora pueden explorar diez veces más posibilidades. Estas herramientas los están haciendo muchísimo más eficientes. Y hay gente que dice: "Ay, Dios mío, van a reemplazar a los creativos". No. No, no, no. Para nada. Lo que van a hacer es encontrar soluciones diez veces mejores.
key_sentence: Creative pros explore 10X the surface area of possibility, finding 10X better solutions.
